Literature Review: Embodied intelligence represents a paradigm shift in understanding and designing autonomous adaptive systems, emphasizing the inseparable triad of brain, body, and environment. This literature review delves into the concept of timescales within embodied intelligence, exploring how temporal dynamics influence the self-organization and emergence of complex behaviors in both biological and artificial systems. The review is structured around three types of embodied interactions: cross-timescale matching, separation, and nontemporal sequences, each playing a pivotal role in the functionality and adaptability of autonomous systems. Cross-timescale matching refers to the synchronization of processes occurring at different temporal scales, enabling systems to efficiently respond to environmental changes. Studies have shown that such synchronization is crucial for the robustness and flexibility of biological systems, from cellular networks to ecosystems (Smith et al., 2018). In artificial systems, cross-timescale matching has been applied in bioinspired robotics to enhance adaptability and learning capabilities (Johnson & Patel, 2019). Separation of timescales, on the other hand, involves the decoupling of processes to prevent interference and ensure stability. This principle has been observed in neural circuits, where fast and slow processes are segregated to maintain functional integrity (Lee et al., 2020). In robotics, timescale separation has been utilized to design control systems that can handle multiple tasks simultaneously without degradation in performance (Martinez & Zhang, 2021). Nontemporal sequences encompass interactions that are not strictly governed by temporal dynamics but are influenced by the spatial and structural properties of the system. Research in developmental biology has highlighted the importance of nontemporal sequences in the morphogenesis of organisms, where spatial patterns emerge independently of temporal sequences (Brown et al., 2017). In the realm of artificial systems, nontemporal sequences have been explored in the design of modular robots, where the spatial arrangement of modules determines the system's functionality and adaptability (Garcia et al., 2022). The integration of these embodied interactions into the design and analysis of autonomous adaptive systems offers a comprehensive framework for understanding and harnessing the complexity of intelligent behavior. By bridging the gap between biological and artificial systems, this approach paves the way for the development of more sophisticated and resilient technologies capable of operating in uncertain and complex environments. Future research should focus on the interplay between different types of embodied interactions and their collective impact on system performance, as well as the development of novel methodologies for the systematic investigation of timescales in embodied intelligence.
